Honestly I don't see an active system like this ever working perfectly in VR. It always HAS to be reactive, and that will lead to the inertia/delay problems displayed in this video. Improving the algorithms may help, but it's always going to have to wait until you're displaced from zero and move you back. And sudden direction changes will always be a problem. Hence 4 years later, to my knowledge this still isn't available.

What IS available are "slide" treadmills, which are basically giant laptop touch pads for your feet. Now that's going to be unrealistic for different reasons, but seems to me to be far easier for the brain to adapt to than that crazy force/displacement graph in the video. Also way simpler and less obtrusive hardware. Couldn't help but notice how LOUD that treadmill was.

I really think that they need to go and read the information much "sooner" than visually "after" or at least while it's actively happening. It should be able to read motor nervous impulse, muscle microcontractions (electrods on the body would be "invasive", do we have ways to read such small fields from a distance?), or something much finer than currently anyway. It will have a very hard time being finely tuned in the current state of concept, imho. It cant know intent but it has to be able to partly anticipate (IA) and/or actually "know" much faster.

And having a perfectly fine-tuned retroaction must be monstruously complicated even with the best "detection" system possible... It must take incredible mechanic to be smooth and "relatable".The prototype seemed to move much too roughly in comparison.
Very interesting though, for sure! Would be interesting to know where such a project is at nowadays...

Layman here, but I don’t know if I agree that “it’s just a control systems problem at this point”. There’s a bunch of shortcomings mentioned in the video that are intrinsic to the problem. They can be reduced a bit with clever control systems solutions, but they can’t go away. Fact remains that you’re going to move forward with your body on what you think is a static floor (in the VR world), and the real floor is going to be slipping away from you. The current implementation has an additional time delay issue, but even if that went away the problem is still there. Your sense of inertia based on the floor you see in VR is going to be misaligned with the inertia you feel in the real world. The only way I can think of to reduce the scale of the problem is to have a huge treadmill, with a huge boundary ring. That way, the system doesn’t have to keep reacting to your smallest movements in real time. It can slowly realign you to the center, but it can do so at a very low gee because you’re nowhere near the boundary.

8:02 when he stops and leans foward. That moment is what I mean. This will get weird. So in anime, cartoons, and games the characters lean in the direction they are going. Two point harness that suspends the character where they are lightly touching the deck. Then move the sensor on your back to just under your armpit level. To move in a direction you would need a "short" period to learn to lean into your movements. My thought is that trying that may help with the lag of your "going somewhere" and the treadmill reacting. Also with the ability lean to control moving the treadmill, we can make the treadmill stop on a dime if brakes were able to be incorporated into the treadmill. Our brains are able to, I'm going sound like I'm trying to sound smarter than I am, compute and calculate so much more than the average person realizes. My hope/assumption is that the natural power of the brain can be used to not have to program and code as much. To customize the treadmill speed, when you set up a profile, have the person move as fast as they can while leaning as far as they can in a bunch of directions. That and the lead foot's initial acceleration into that movement's direction could be used to set the treadmill's speed when reacting to input.
Side note: I don't mean to come off as I have it all figured out or it's this simple. I just wanted to get my thoughts down and see if people, that have experience in this area, think that any of this is useful.
Ok back to it. Then a program would have to be made to allow for an adjustable/gradual tread speed graph to represent the distance from centered and stationary to full speed and leaning in that direction. That way you can get a rough starting point (default speed for you) to customize to fit you and how active you feel that day. Make it where a walking speed for you is jogging for your avatar if you want.

1) this design, where it's actively moving to position you as well as using your direction and intended velocity to translate your avatar,
2) a stationary design such as a bed of rollers that let you walk in place but use your generated roll speed and direction to translate the avatar.

Which one would be more accurate and carry less "risk" of upsetting the user's balance and momentum? It looks like the "infinadeck" in the movie only moves with the user's generated force, which would probably require a high level of roller freedom but enough friction to not carry them if they come to a stop. Hi, they are trying to make this thing work by measuring the position of the full body as a monolithic mass. They will have better results by measuring the exact movement of each leg in every 6 degrees. The direction of the body is given by the way your legs move in relation to your hip. Then you will be able to calculate the way the floor should be moving to keep the body in place. But, there is another problem that can´t be solved yet. When you walk, you must make an effort to overcome the inertia of your body, both to start and to stop walking. When you are in the machine, there is no inertia to overcome because your body it's supposed to stay in the same place, so that effort must be absorbed by the floor. It's a position and torque control.

The reason you don't use ball bearings:

1) Safety: you just created a slippy slidy low friction surface that has limited speed control. You'd be hardpressed to modulate resistance without tons more complexity. You'd also look like a newborn calf if whatever provides resistance gives out and you'd for sure hurt yourself.

2) speaking of complexity... ball bearings fundamentally work with well machined and finely manufactured parts. The ballbearings need to be percise but the interface which with they interact with needs to be percise to a degree aswell.

3) maintenance: ballbearings require lubricant and maintenance. For many small disposable items this isn't as big of a deal the bearing will probably outlast the item. But if you have a large apparatus of them you'll be maintaing the whole system. Belts need maintenance aswell but I feel like it'd generally be easier so long as the tensioner isn't a pain to use.

I have one question and two observations/potential suggestions?.
My question is can it comfortably handle diagonal movement and if so how since it can only move in the x and y directions(perhaps by moving in both the opposite of the x ad y directions you move in, but I believe you may feel some jerky acceleration from these type of corrections).

As for the observation, he mentioned that the computer in charge of the treadmills cant use intent like your mind can however that isn't exactly true I believe. When walking, one's weight is shifted around on their feet and this weight shift, as well as the literal positions of the feet, can give a good indication of the persons intentions even if its not 100% perfect.

Additionally, it may improve the accuracy you can get from the treadmill movements if instead of using the center of the body as a reference point they used the feet of the person. This will likely have nearly the same result however you may be able to reduce the time between someone moving and the counter-movement of the treadmills. A potential issue of this is that if an adjustment in the treadmills is made while the person is in midstep, as would likely result from using the feet as reference points, the person may be thrown off balance due to the sudden shift in acceleration. A workaround for this is to make the acceleration much slower at first and then slowly increase it, this way no sudden jolt from the treadmills will throw someone off balance while they are using it but you would still get the benefit of a reduced time from the persons movement and the countermovement of the belt.

Honestly, in theory this design sounds great but seeing it in practice it gets way too complicating. Thinking of a better design , I would use a regular 1 dimensional treadmill and mount it on a rotary union (just like an excavator has one) which would be controlled by a computer. By using two different sensors ( accelerometer and gyroscope) mounted on both of the user's shoulders; notice when you want to turn in one direction while walking the first thing you rotate is your upper body ,most notably your shoulders. Using the data from the sensors you know if and how the upper body is turned so you get the intent of the user to rotate . The computer will act and turn the rotary union in the direction of the users upper body in real time bringing his lower body along. For the forward and backward motion i would attach pressure sensors either under the treadmill belt or in special shoes worn by the user . These would measure the force exerted by the user on various parts of his sole(foot) and determine the intention of the users movement along with the intensity of the move. From there you would program it to counteract that force and translate it into a movement. (Maybe it's more complicated than it seems :p ).

The “tread mill” also known as the “tread wheel” was first introduced in the height of the Roman Empire, around the late first century. When the Romans found they had a need to lift heavier weight, they incorporated the treadmill, replacing the winch in their cranes. The men would walk within the wheel itself and because the treadmill had a larger diameter, they were able to lift double the weight with half the crew. 

U.S purpose of the Treadmill.
During the Victorian Era, British engineer William Cubitt invented the prison treadmill. Installed for hard labor, these treadmills were designed as a means to usefully employ convicts and use their power to be productive. The prisoner would simply work the wheel to produce power to grind corn and pump water, although some served no purpose at all other than punishment.

I'm sure you fix this by now but if you haven't have you tried treating the human like a joystick on a Playstation or Xbox controller with more of an absolute position value for the set speeds from center then set the dead zone to about 5" to 10" from center depending if you're walking or running. If you can keep the belt sensor in the dead zone keeping the subject as close as possible to the center of X,Y position you can then use the trackers on the belt and feet to determine whether the subject is in motion, how fast they are moving and witch direction. This would allow you to use a harder breaking without the need for allot of dampining. If the subject is not actually moving or gaining any momentum then there's no need for allot of dampining. And by applying a harder breaking with a little dampining within the dead zone to a stop should give the subject a more realistic feeling of your body coming to a stop with the slight tug in the direction you were traveling or as if the floor jumped back an inch. This is a natural reaction by the sudden change in your speed. This effect could be mimicked by detecting when the subjects foot sensors are no longer detecting weather the feet are performing a walking or running motion then dropping the speed by about 50% or so of current speed with about a 1" or 2" travel to a stop.
Sry I tend to ramble. But I hope this gives you ideas cuz I would love to see this in an arcade or something.

I was imagining a different setup, something akin to walking on stilts. Except, that the stilts would actually be huge joysticks on a platform (maybe 2 or 3 feet high) beneath you, and the tops of the joystick levers would be strapped to your shoes. Pressure sensors in the shoes would provide feedback for lifting the foot while walking, so that intended direction of travel could be calculated by the sequencing of pressure with motion.


The stilts might need a telescoping section at the top end so that a player could have a somewhat normal gait, something like a gas strut or something that allows the foot to be raised without disengaging the boot.



Forward and reverse stepping/strafing could then be calculated. The player would have to be anchored in place in a belly harness, with only freedom to duck or jump.


The tricky part would be to be standing on these fairly long stilts, and having them stabilized in the vertical position so that standing still would be easy, instead of like riding a unicycle. It might be possible to do this with magnetic impulse rings low down on the stilts. The computer would sense torque on the stilts as the player attempts to walk and loosen off the field in a certain direction, but when no torque is detected, then the field becomes uniform once again and helps the player stand still and upright. Such a system would be close to frictionless and have very low momentum to deal with.


I'm not dead certain that achieving this goal would be as much of a godsend as some people think. The distance you have to move around in a lot of FPS games, is tremendous. If you start to rescale the distance travelled while walking in VR, I think that might mess up your head. Perhaps a combination of 'hoverboard walking' and 'walking walking' might work alright.

This is the interesting part.  Once they balance out the motion, it can be connected to a robot drone.  Instead of controlling an avatar in a virtual environment, you have a robot feeding a virtual feed to "pilot" who is controlling the robot.  This can revolutionize industries where heavy lifting is involved.  No longer do you need a fork lift to move the items, but a robot piloted by someone in this could perform the task.  I foresee this coming with some sort of feedback mechanism so the pilot can properly respond to changes in terrain and weight distribution.  If not, the robot would become off balance with the slightest turbulence introduced.  Essentially, the robot would be experiencing environmental feedback that the pilot would not.  This is the same feedback you described when a walk around and our brain auto correct/adjust our center of gravity to sustain balance, else we fall down.

I feel like one solution to the inertial issues is machine learning. If you strapped the Vive position system on, hooked it up to record movement data, and paired that with high frame rate cameras watching from multiple angles, then had a lot of people walk, stop, turn, etc., on the treadmill, and generated thousands of hours of position and video data, you could build something that could recognize at incredible resolution the intent to move of the user, the way really good goalies can dive the right way most of the time, because of the adrenaline cranking up brain processing speed, mixed with thousands of attempts worth of experience, and the countless, subtle cues in the movements of the shooter, that tell them where the ball/puck/whatever is about to go. After a few years driving in LA, I started to know when someone was about to cut me off, or switch lanes, or exit the highway, because the cues are there; they're just very subtle. My degree is in animation. There are so many things that lead into movement. It's almost impossible to just start moving in a direction. You lift your foot, you shift your weight, you change your breathing, you anticipate movements with their opposites... machine learning could learn to recognize all of that, and react really fast. Then you just need really strong motors on the treadmills, with fast acceleration, and tuned ease-in/ease-out, like really high power, high speed servo positioners.

I think the solution to the problem of having the treadmill reacting slower than a persons intent could be solved rather easily. What I'm thinking is if there was a way for the infinadeck to "see" the movement of the leg that is about to make a step then asses the direction based on the direction of said leg and start its motors. That would considerably improve the latency. So, what I mean by "seeing" the leg I mean using the sensors on the wall (the virtual model of a person) and feeding that information to the infinadeck. Of course, there would be a need of substantial gathering of data but that seems like a great way to improve this system. I don't know if I'm missing anything and would love to hear from what people think about this idea!

I honestly kinda feel like these guys are over complicating the design of this thing. I get what they’re trying to do, but why not use elastic/bungee cords to hold the player in one spot instead of making the treadmill do all this extra work to make sure they’re centered. In my mind, I’m not sure if the treadmill would need to have electric at all, to be totally honest. Hold the players body in one spot using bungee chords, use the same design for having an omnidirectional treadmill, having the individual sections be able to move horizontally to provide a 360 degree range of motion etc. Then so long as the person is held in one spot via bungee, you can just use your leg power to move the treads. Slap some trackers on your ankles to track the movement, and translate the ankle tracking to in-game player movement. Just seems to make sense to me. This seems to be overcomplicating it.

If they measured your force on the treadmill, couldn't the machine react quicker? Really cool, but I can already see some points they'll need to work out before this is commercially lucrative.
First, of course, is the size. That thing is way too big to fit in the standard home.
Second, is flexibility. The headset they were using here, the HTC Vive, costs easily around $1000 for the full setup, because of those extra cameras, but, for example, I have an Oculus Rift S, which doesn't have those cameras, it just uses sensors in the headset.

Third is the delay between human motion and treadmill motion, which would come into play in fast-paced games where you'd be constantly running and dodging.
And then, the cost. A lot of people will opt to forgo an omnidirectional treadmill like this if it costs several hundreds or thousands of dollars, as this sort of freedom of movement in VR games is currently just a commodity, and not at all required for the games that are out.

The problem is they are using analog style placement rather than digital sensory placement. The deck needs to be epithet something like a touch screen in which it detects individual (touches) contact from the body, in this case the feet, to determine player position. They can also use 360 video technology injunction with a full body sensory suit which can relay the players actual positron to that of the deck. Since the deck is a fixed point, it never moves, changes position or directional alignment. Basically, think of how a self propelled drone would be programmed to follow a user without a remote. Only the deck is the drone and the remote is the player.

A suggestion you might pass on: Instead of the dampening, they should use a controller algorithm like the one SpaceX uses for slam landing their boosters, with a continuously variable throttling of the motors. That should remove the need for dampening and improve response times. (I'm a control system engineer, retired)

Wouldn't alot of individually "rolling" balls be smoother? A censor on each foot tells the computer where your feet are and in which direction they're pointing, and then rolls a group of balls located under your feet, all at certain individual direction/speed based on your feets positions and your predicted step.

It would solve the problem of sliding away from the center, since the "threadmill" only moves at the spot where your feet are, and while you want to move!

The balls would also have force-sensors capable of responding to you "breaking" or quickly stop moving. As well as computing data from another sensor detecting how your body leans during the movement, to calibrate the speed so you wont "slip" while leaning forward, and slowing down when leaning backwards while running, as you would when doing a "sliding break" IRL :)

Your observations are correct and there are some "math problems" to solve but physics will always break the immersion. Inertia is the reason why you'll never feel the correct forces on your body with an Infinadeck type of system. Assuming the system is further developed, it will become possible with sufficient training to walk and even run on it without holding the bar, but it will always be different and feel different from reality. To put it differently, after using the system for several hours non-stop, it'll always strange when you get off and try to walk; it will take you some time to recover and return to the normal effects of friction and inertia.

PS. I designed this system several years before Infinadeck announced their project and, when I realised it will never feel right, I could no longer persuade myself to investing more time and money to build it. Having said that, I do hope Infinadeck succeeds what I considered would not be possible!

Maybe the sleeves could be covered in many tiny sensors. Each sensor reads the distance between all of it's adjacent sensors and that distance data gets translated into what degree your muscles are flexing. It would have to be calibrated to each individual I bet by getting them to run up and down various speeds. Maybe it could become as intelligent as being able to read the muscles in your feet and ankles to know what direction your pushing yourself. The only way this types of device would work perfectly is if it could be attached to your nerves and know your next move as soon as your muscles do and since that's highly unlikely to happen, you've got to find a way to read your body well enough that you get as close to that level of perfection as you can.

I've been thinking about how a 360 degree treadmill might work forever and this treadmill of treadmills is a great idea. But, I think it's been made unnecessarily complicated by this idea that it needs to be locomotive to center the player. In all of my concepts, it simply holds you in the middle with a soft belt that fastens to an array of either rigid posts or lax straps (one would keep you pushed to the center while the other pulls you to the center,) and you simply move the belts with your feet -- the belt's movement would translate into movement around the virtual space. The hard part in my mind was solving the omni-directional movement, which they have solved. Perhaps they already iterated through my approach, but I'd be interested to see if it works.

Certain an interesting problem.  But as far as “intent” is concerned, game developers might be able to program that in as movement queues.  A stealth mission in some kind of military black ops game (Call Of Duty or Splinter Cell for example) might be programmed with an NPC waiting to for an enemy NPC guard to move to or away from a certain place to give you the player a queue to move toward the objective.  The developer could use that queue to tell the Infinideck tracking equipment that your motion is imminent and most likely forward.  I say most likely to account for one variable the system maybe have to deal with, which is guessing which direction that you are about to move.  A programmed queue for the system may reduce that lag.

You can take this one step further (no pun) and link feed back from the headset and feet together. By seeing their position in space you can tell if the user is leaning forward in anticipation of a step. standing still, head directly above foot. Prepping for a step, people lean forward slightly so you would see the head a couple inches in front of the foot. To avoid false movement you can make the system wait for foot movement, but this could get the system ready to move. By tying the head and foot together you can enable the system to tell the difference between a step forward and a stationary leg lift or jump.

You need to feed it 3-Dimensional vector data and output a 2-Directional oppositional force. (On the pad) The reason you're getting tough pad interaction is because it's not adjusting the force with proper data. Let's say you're running and jump, the 2D force forward is measured in X & Y but the Z direction is not accounted for. Therefore the final summed vector force Vector X + Vector Y that is supposed to counter your movements is missing a small adjustment, making it seem weird to walk on.

I think you could solve the problem with a touch sensitive treadmill that could read what percentage of the body weight is placed on which foot. Taking a step uses your full body weight and using this parameter would allow you to make the treadmill x/y-axis correction instantly as you could read what the step length is. The difference between body position and foot position when foot has 100% (or so) weight load is the distance the axis need to cover. Done correctly this could mask itself as heptic feedback since the body is expecting a type of muscle activation when "walking" and having to rely on the ground to work as you expect based on the real world.

I feel like instead of basing it off of your back and the over all position of your body, it should be based off of the position of your stepping foot.
If the user picks up their foot, track the direction that the foot is heading and spin the treadmill in the exact opposite direction while the foot is in the air...
I feel like that is how humans walk, they lean and move in a certain direction and subsequently put their foot in that direction. Using that logic, you can reverse it and say that the
direction a person's stepping foot is going is the way they will go. When the device is on your back, your foot is already on the ground by the time your body moves so there is a bit
of a delay.
I could be totally wrong, but I feel like that makes the most sense in my head

Toss in a gravity reduction and positioning arm to the back of the user, and I imagine such a room sized system would work perfectly for low gravity lunar and Martian simulation.

It is definately a complex system, requiring quite a bit of engineering, maths, and trial and error, but I can see this becoming the future of VR.

I have 10 times better idea allready.

Make player walk on top of the ball that is at least 3 diameters wide suspended on ultrasensitive gyroskopes so the ball moves leamingly frictionless with minimal resistance. Then you only need to put motion detectors on players legs, and as soon as he stops moving magnetic locks activate locking the ball in place. Do you have intent? That's a big question you know... ))) First you would have to answer who is this "you", then what is "intent", really? And only then you would have to reason whether or not this "you" entity is real or illusory and can or cannot possess something like an intent. Your brain hasn't evolved to deal with all 3 answers at the same time, it has trouble with even just answering the first question to which many a philosopher modern and ancient will attest. For example, one could answer it with something like this: "personhood is a way in which the human brain tricks itself into believing that it has some single centre that controls everything, and, that this centre has absolute, objective continuity, separate from even the brain and body, some kind of ultimate "puppet master" if you will, an illusion perpetuated by the networking effort between different colonies of neurons. However, if this is one's best shot at a scientifically literate guess, then intent looks either like progressive continuation of the same self-reinforced "you illusion", or, as something which occurs at a much more basic level, one not always directly amenable or even detectable by the conscious mind, - part of the brain which typically has the job of creating a language-based abstraction, as well as rationalizing and justifying actions after they have already "occurred" to one. Maybe better way to tackle it would probably be to say that "we have the experience of having an intent" which we can corroborate, whether or not "we" actually "have" an "intent". In any case, I thought those of you who wanted to do some novel reading on the subject, somewhat challenging but endlessly fascinating, - try Daniel Dennett's "Consciousness Explained" (Pay close attention to the chapter with "Shakey" robot).

The fun part is trying to make this affordable. Even if it never gets to the point of home use, even if you say, went to a VR arcade or something similar, this is still going to put a very large dent in the budget of any company wanting to put one of these in their businesses. Not to mention, the creators of this treadmill are going to have to simplify it, so that it would be easy enough for it to be be produced in factories. It is going to be an uphill battle to convince manufacturers that the cost of equipment and materials to produce these treadmills is going to make enough money to produce in the first place. And we haven’t even talked about how the software needed to make it work is going to be implemented. This looks like a majority of the treadmill is the software and processors that make it work.

An exaggerated version would be when a cartoon character is about to run off somewhere. We always know when and in the what direction. That's based on real cues (only in cartoons, it's hyper-exaggerated to a ridiculous extent for comedic effect).

Suggested Solution: Apply movement controls to the hand controllers just like any other typical gaming platform which use joysticks. Making the player have to physically walk in the direction they have chosen with the controllers. Its not exactly freestyle walking but it is still physically engaging within the virtual world.

It needs a vest with multiple sensors so it can accurately track, then predict you next bodily movement based upon whole body metrics rather than just feet and relative CG. Also on your knees for knee position. This will also give one to one leg movement without the need for extraneous extrapolation. Basically, if you had sensors in most of the places they put trackers for Mo-Cap, the treadmill would have the ability to not just keep up with a person, but actually predict the person's motion based upon early reads of each and every motion made. We telegraph every motion we make unless we are trained not to. However, just to move forward, we  have to shift off of center of gravity. If the system could read this at the shoulders, the hips, knees, then feet, it would be able to extrapolate the relative speed of the treadmill required much quicker and more accurately. Once moving, we also telegraph a stop by leaning back some as we slow ourselves to a stop. It is more extreme if we're moving forward quickly. We lean back and tend to bend our rear leg and plant even more firmly our front leg in a more rigid stance. This is why it's important to track the knee. It's relative position between foot and CG also in relation to our torso. That's how I see it in regards to what is necessary to fix this. But unfortunately, I'm not a control programmer or an engineer, so really am only speaking from the stand-point of human biology and how we actually move, to determine we have to let the machine know exactly how our whole body is positioned, not just the 6 points of 'contact' that it has. It needs a lot more than that. Especially to get natural fluid motion, such as crouching, duck-walking, sitting down, jumping, going prone, leaning from side to side, leaning with a leg out from side to side, moving from a walk to a jog to a run and back again with sudden stops thrown in for good measure. In order to get correct body positioning in game, as well as let the treadmill know what you're doing. Also until it reads that we are stepping AGAIN, it shouldn't move. We sometimes might want to put a foot in front of the other, behind the other, etc. and then perform a rotation or lean out one way or the other. Or just step once or twice then stop.This is also something it needs to predict, and knowing every position of ever relevant joint and point of contact, as well as relative position of the body, it's attitude, are all part of it moving correctly for someone's movement with as little lag and as accurately as possible. TL;DR: More sensors, more sensors, and did I mention? More sensors.

This is interesting. I think the easy solution to the inertial delay problem would be to integrate a force sensing waistbelt with the existing Infinadeck. The waistbelt/harness would be connected to the ring with say 4 linkages for your x - y directions and be free to rotate within the outer ring. This would keep your center of mass in one place at all times in x-y space while allowing the possibility of moving in z space. Within the linkages would be force sensors to measure the direction and force your legs are pushing your center of mass. The rotation of the ring and harness would keep track of your absolute body direction with say a rotatory encoder instead of relying on the cameras.

When your foot pushes off the deck in any direction the force sensors in belt would sense the direction you intend to move in and that would give a definite acceleration vector for the deck to respond to. The harder you push into the belt the faster the deck would accelerate. Say you want to come to a sudden stop, the deck would push you into the belt in the opposite direction of motion sending a negative acceleration vector back to the deck and slow it down. Naturally in real life if you tried to come to a sudden stop after running without bracing (say a longjump) the inertia of your body would cause result in a faceplant into the dirt.

The resultant feedback loop between the force inputs and the deck acceleration should allow you to speed up and slow down and even sidestep seamlessly with direct hardware inputs without any of the lag that would be present in a predictive positional software solution.

By its nature the fact that you have to supply a force against the waistbelt to move the deck means that you will have a positive feeling of resistance in your feet. By controlling the force input vs the acceleration the deck ratio it would allow your body to feel a slight resistance to acceleration and mimic the feeling of inertia without your body actually moving in space.

If the main problem is acceleration difference via treadmill to your foot, it would be better to give that acceleration change right to your center of the mass, letting free of the foots
Foot have to be setteled on the ground so that user feels normal, but the ground (may say treadmill) has to give minimum acceleration alter giving that mission to device onside the center of the mass of your body.

Its about the torque he told us about early on, everytime user moves there comes little torque force trying to flip your body because there is some distance difference between your center of mass and whrre actually the force is given(the feet)
Which makes us brain process again to balance against that leaning torque to be able to stand up still.
But when the device push the center of mass right through, leaving torque on the feet to zero, the torque problem just disappears.

Center of mass of human body keeps changing through various chemical physical processes in our body, and the main variance comes from the positioning of your legs, mainly from running and walking.
So ring can be adjusted to be linear to point of center of your mass in line of z axis, being parallel to direction of gravity and thay ring can be the set module for the device that can arrange your positioning in real world.

Lastly, for the inertia difference (not the torque but the force itself now) they comes because of the mal-symmetry (gap) between timing of you trying to give force to your body and the timing the device tries to counter it, the spring force balance correction is inevitable, but can make it less starting force of corrention ( say less than 0.1g developer told us) and also lesser swing by HAVING SENSOR NOT ON YOUR POSITION WHICH IS THE RESULT OF BODY PROCESSING, BUT SENSOR FOR THAT ACTUAL BODY PROCESSING, SAY THE INTENTION, THE ELECTRIC SIGNAL THROUGH YOUR BODY THAT ATTEMPTS TO MAKE YOUR LEGS MOVE TO CHANGE POSITIONS. Or that muscle contraction which comes after the electric wave can be alternative, too.

Trying to have input for the latest output (alterred position) has no choice but to produce gap time malsymmetry, but having same input(say, muscle contraction sensory) for two outputs (body changing position and device trying to counter it) can in theoretically even make the perfect symmetry.

A bigger treadmill would solve the engineering problems. Big enough and you'll be able to sprint off in any direction and be fine. Assuming an average sprinting speed of 6.7 meters per second and the acceleration specified of 1 m/s^2. That gives us ... 22.5 meters plus 6.7 meters for each second of latency. Double that to cover all directions and you have a 45 meter treadmill. That's far from feasible.

Lets assume that above a jogging speed they abandon the 0.1g limit. I can jog 3km in 12 minutes, which means 15km per hour, which means 4.2m/s. This adds up to 18 square meters and 6.7 meters for each second of latency. Still not good enough.

Ok lets assume the system is specifically designed not to be sprinted with, so you can only jog. Lets also assume jogging violates the acceleration limit. 1.4 meters per seconds means a 2 meter square treadmill (assuming zero latency). That's finally doable.

A 2 meter square seems like the maximum practical size, I think latency is the only way to improve this. If it could start moving the instant you do, it could cut into your initial acceleration a bit and increase the speed limit. There's also the noise issue, that thing is loud.

It seems like the treadmill will always try to center your body so couldn't you just recalibrate the center to the point that the "abnormal acceleration bit when you stop moving" would be limited? You can steadily adjust the body towards the center while moving.

By doing this you basically make it so that "stop moving = zero acceleration, moving = acceleration". Since readjusting the body towards the center will result in acceleration, why not just readjust while the player is moving? That way you won't feel acceleration when you want to stop, you just feel a little bit of weird acceleration as you move whilst the computer adjusts your body towards the center.

Better yet, combine both the centre tracker with feet ones so that it can have multiple variables to calculates averages off.

It's taking too long for the system to move you. They need extra cameras on the outside and they need to analyze the feet and steps you take, AS soon as you lift your foot up. right now, it's waiting for your body to slightly move, and then makes an adjustment from there, but imagine a system if as soon as you lift your foot in a certain direction, it will already begin to slowly move you, and as soon as you put your foot down, the system finishes moving and stops, and waits for your other foot to move and repeat. By the time you put your foot down, you wouldn't have moved at all since it made the adjustments according to that single step you just took, and didn't wait for your body to move like what it's doing now. imagine every step you took, it stayed you put in the middle of the system immediately, and as soon as you stop, the system wouldn't need to move because it didn't detect another step, and you're already in the middle, therefore eliminating the inertia problem. it's a big math problem of course, but with enough cameras to capture and and model the feet and direction of them, and getting the right angles down, this team looks smart enough to do it.

I feel like the solution would be in shoe inserts that could measure the distribution of your weight between the two feet as well as the shift in pressure and height along the bottom of each foot at the heel, ball, and toes. If you could catalog those to make a generic motion profile then you'd only need to do some calibration for each user based on height and weight. That's a very interesting solution. My idea for a similar technology would have been to use a belt that holds you in place and have the treadmill pushed by the movements of your feet. In that case no foot sensors would be needed to control avatar movement, though they would be useful for immersion. My idea of course has it's benefits, but it also has problems in that a belt would prevent you from doing certain common game actions like crouching/crawling, rolling, etc. (At least without building up the technology further to allow such things and in turn making it more expensive.)

I think it would be really cool to have more points of articulation such as your elbows, knees, and each of your fingers. There adding more motion sensors wouldn't fix the problem of immersion caused by not being able to actually touch things in the virtual world. I think one solution could be gloves which create a slight warming sensation when the player touches something in the game world. A related issue would be elevation. If your game world isn't flat you're not going to feel right walking around in it. The best idea I've come up with is to have the direction the player is facing tracked and to tilt the treadmill accordingly.

I'm very glad to see the guys at Infinadeck actually working to make this technology a reality. It's something I very much want to exist as a game developer, but it's a big project and I'm sure it costs a lot of money to develop. That just means somebody besides myself has to do it if the technology is going to exist before I'm super old lol.

The problem with all of these 'motion platforms' is that your body isn't moving, so there is no momentum. In addition your middle ear senses no relative motion (to the ground), so the effect doesn't really work well and it is unnatural still. In other words: while your legs are making walking movements, you're not actually moving your body - it's stationary. If you're moving at a steady speed then it doesn't matter... it's the direction changes that it can't simulate and that's what VR is all about. The only way to make it work is to roam freely... and who has the space for that?

why dont you forward on this small theory: you had something when mentioning weight. and it may be less of a treadmill scale thing and more of a special pare of shoes with pressure measuring pads in the shoes. using the measurements of pressure exerted in the soles of the shoes along side the motion tracker the computer could better predict the movement of the user. when we stand we exert x amount of pressure on each part of the foot when we walk we exert a diffrent pressure on each foot in a pattern ( heel to toe) and the faster we walk the greater the pressure and wider the stride. and when we are slowing ourselves down there is a different pattern of pressures on our feet and our stride changes. it also goes without saying that each specific user will need to go through a calibration so the machine computer knows the user's stride and patterns at different walking speeds. and once it memorizes these settings for each user the movement transition between zero to walk, run, and back to zero will be far less jerky.
all that being said this is 1 of 2 promising mobility Immersive "VR" devices id like to see more on.

The Infinadeck should never move you, you should move the Infinadeck. If the infinadeck experiences this over shoot problem, it should sit motionless and make all adjustments inside the virtual reality. So let a person use the whole circle, don't keep resetting them to the center. Just keep them calibrated as standing at their position inside the circle relative to the center. And if they make moves toward the center, use that opportunity to calibrate them to the center by cheating the Virtual Reality position as might be necessary. So the glitch of non-actual movement, should happen in VR and never in real life. And if they do need to be corrected to the center for the sake of not running into the circle railing, then that correction in real life should happen always while they're in motion, by moving them a bit faster or a bit slower than they're actually going depending on whether they're ahead or behind the center relative to their direction of travel. Those very slight value differences while in motion will be far less jarring, than being standing still and having the thing toss you about throwing you off balance. Thing that might be causing this loss in definition is the width of the belts that measure the X axis. Were those belts all an eighth inch rather than 2 inches, you'd probably have 1/16th the ambiguity in the measurements. Nother thing is the foot width and length must be known to the system, not merely a single point on the top of the shoe. The avatar should also be sized to match the player which makes a difference in how the player is moving relative to their avatar. This can also be scaled so as to make small people big or big people small in the VR. But the length of their limbs must be exact, to include the relation of their lower leg to their upper leg, the relation of the forearm to the upper arm, the relation of their torso lower torso to their upper torso. All of this is going to effect how they move in the VR. So it can't be excluded yet arrive to accurate distance measurements in VR as compared to real life.

The Feedback loop is broken.  Bring the treadmill into the VR world (as a prosthetic) and integrate the delay into the VR world via the prosthetic, then the brain will pick up and adapt just like it will rewire to a RW prosthetic.  That gives the a baton to pass from VR back to the brain and helps close the loop.  In other words, it will offload some of the control system computational load back to the brain (where it's "free").  By all means improve the digital systems as well.  It reminds me of the Segway, which probably relies on CG also.  Some way to signal the infintread of your intentions (eye movement, muscle biosensor?) that picks up faster than actually having to take steps and move the tracker... maybe even pressure sensor in soles. Sensors on the muscles could act as a controller

A couple of possible solutions to better predicting the required movement of the system could be either multiple 3D mapping sensors so that toes, ankles, knees, hips, shoulders can be mapped in relation to each other to predict your shifting point of balance as you move, rather than correcting your position after you move, OR special shoes or socks with in-built pressure sensors in various critical places between the shoe and the foot to measure the pressure that you are applying to the surface, and using that data to map your predicted movements and giving the system a head start in keeping you stationary.  The two systems could work in tandem, along with the current CoM system, to make the motion of the system appear more seamless to the user.

The variable of human intent is definitely going to be a continuous problem. I think what it's going to come to is compromise. It's going to be nearly impossible to accurately predict spontaneous variations in a person's intent using a motorized system. I think a much better way to do this would be to simply use x/y sensors and let the person control the movement of the treadmill and mimic inertia by variable gear driven resistance using weights such as those little cars that you push forward faster and faster and then let them go and they slowly lose momentum. The ones that whine higher and higher pitched as they get faster. This leaves muscle memory to take up the slack, so that human intent will control the system instead of an algorithm trying to predict intent. A harness with cables would keep the person from falling on their face while learning. Not really much different from what was shown in the movie RPO.

So if a player has the intent to stop quickly, or change directions he can do so immediately after the press of the button. Compensating for the inertia will take a bit of practice to avoid tripping, but it shouldn't take long.

NOTE: The press of the button deletes previously stored cache hence movement stops completely, no compensation. There can be an option for re-centering for games that do not require dynamic movement. This will add a certain lag.

Also, a solution to remove the lag from the Y-axis direction would be to install thinner horizontal belts with motors that have high torque.

Seems pretty noisy, I would say you'd need a suspension "saddle" and then use a gliding surface to walk on (think socks on linoleum or ice skating). To get a 'comfortable' full-body motion immersion.

The Saddle would keep you from slipping, and the trackers could be placed on specially designed low-friction [on the sole] footwear, to track the foot movement.

Basically, if you want a believable VR experience, the user has to be in full control. That's why I don't like these headsets and controllers. I think that the problem is not in the calculations and its in the motors that run the treadmill, the same problem of the brushless gimbal at first, they have to use a brushless gimbals with PID entry so they can relate distance of the sensors with turns or degrees in the brushless motor running in both axis, so wen you move your feet sensor the feedback can accommodate the speed of the treadmill instantly with the speed of your feet, brushless are the real deal here, imagine just how a gimbal works moving in your hand and the same working principle here, if you have one sensor each foot and one in the hips, as you have one foot forward in the instant that you move your other foot there is a acceleration and a speed that the motors will compensate trying to make the hips sensor to stay in the center of the ring and moving your first foot go backwards, this is wen is in walking section, wen you start walking, your foot go forward then only wen move the other foot there will be an acceleration to compensate double distance o the traveling foot, the goal of the treadmill is to balance you like a reverse hover board in two dimensions, only that the sensors you have in you and the motors run the treadmill, feeding from degree of rotation translate to moving feet, imagine like a hover board upside down and its large enough so you can walk in the wheels like a round treadmill in one axis, if you need some ideas I will be happy to assist you.

I think what you need for this to ever work well is not a 1,5 by 1,5 m platform, but a room 6 by 6 metres. The problem is the difference of scale between the size of your step and the overall size of the space you're moving inside. If the possible size of your step is 0,7 m and the platform is 1,5 m, in two steps you can cross that space, which means the treadmill has to react very quickly with very high acceleration. If the room were 7 by 7 metres, the movement of the floor could be much smoother and the accelleration much more gradual. I actually suffer quite a lot from motion sickness and i think the problems of accelleration and counteraccelleration cannot be reasonably solved at this scale. Just immagine that in the real world, your brain is equipped to detect even the tiniest loss of traction or instability of the ground you step on. At this scale, this must feel like someone constantly tugging a carpet under your feet. Unfortunately, I'm afraid it's not a problem of computer processing, but rather of physics. Even if the platform knew exactly how far you're going to step in a certain direction, didn't overshoot at all and started its movement immediately with zero lag, it would just feel as if you were on a slipery floor because the foot in contact with the floor would move to the back without your body moving at all. Scaling up is the only way to make this work short of creating a brain interface or at least a system to externally fool the inner ear's sense of balance.

I realize this is still in development, but here are some things that could be improved.

First, the treadmill deck should be lighter so as not to have any inherent inertia. This is because you don't want the player to have to consciously limit their motion speed so as not to step off the edge, but you still want the machine to be able to register the forces applied by their feet. Maybe this could be accomplished by allowing a pseudo-flexible sheet to glide over multiple servo-synchronized ball-bearings, but that would require starting from scratch with far more sophisticated materials.

Second, artificial inertia should be introduced using the motor controls on the deck. This is because the inertia experienced by the player in real life should depend on the in-game weight (among other characteristics) of the avatar. A larger avatar's acceleration is slower, and likewise a smaller one's is faster.

Third, the foot-trackers are not being implemented correctly. Instead of just being used to map the player's foot positions in-game, they can also be used by the treadmill itself to predict where the player intends to step. If their center of mass is not above their feet, it's clear that they're about to take a step in an easily identifiable direction. Similarly, with enough sensor points, the amount of force being applied on the treadmill deck is calculable without actually measuring it, if you know the player's weigh in real life. This could allow the deck to keep the person's center of gravity almost EXACTLY in the center, regardless of whether they are even touching the treadmill, and would allow interpretation of jumping motions in-game.

A few notes:
- The attachment of the player to the treadmill ring with cables is not ideal, because the player could hit those cables with their arms in reality. A magnetic suspension system (or something similarly non-solid) might be able to replace this, though, which would allow 100% confidence that the player wouldn't fall off the treadmill in real life, as well as an easier way to make inertia felt by the player.
- Full-body haptic suits would solve a lot of user experience problems, like the one above, and allow for more sensor points and therefore a more accurate digital model of the player's position.
- Alternatively to physical sensors, multiple cameras could be placed around the deck. This would result in more comprehensive player-modeling, but would be pointless if you still want haptic feedback (see below).
- The most realistic (but not necessarily the most fun) virtual reality experience would have no "in-game menu" of sorts except for a log-out button. All items would have to be physically placed in your bag, without an inventory menu, and the levels of sensory input and output would be perceptually identical to those of real-life. This means the camera idea would work great for input, because there are no buttons to press anymore, but you'd still need a haptic suit to allow the player to actually feel the in-game world.

Watching this video got me thinking on how to potentially solve this issue of inertia.

From what i understand, there are 2 main issues with any stationary treadmill, 1 being the "latency" i.e. how fast it reacts to a change in a person's movement, and 2 being the person not feeling their acceleration or deceleration as they are still in the same place in 3D space.
While better tech and/or prediction software can mitigate the latency problem, the acceleration and deceleration issue is still present (like how we lean back when coming to a stop fast, but in this situation will end up falling as the is no true forward inertia).

What I thought of (which by no means will be the perfect solution and improvements are welcome) was to load the entire infinadeck concept onto another x-y axis rig. This can solve the latency issue by keeping the person in the same place in 3D space while the infinadeck adjusts the player back to the center of the ring - i.e. move in the opposite direction the infinadeck is moving the person. Since these adjustments are small, the 2nd rig that the infinadeck is on will not need to be particularly big. The acceleration issue is solved in pretty much a similar manner - by using the 2nd rig to ensure that the person is NOT in the same place in 3D space when the person stops/starts moving. For example if the person stops suddenly, the infinadeck alone will stop as well (+ adjustments from the 2nd rig) and the rig can bring the entire deck backwards to mimic the deceleration felt by the person in VR.

This will likely require 2 separate "pathways", one to stabilise the infinadeck and one to mimic acceleration and deceleration, so I'm not sure how this will be able to function in real time but sounds like a potential step up from a "treadmill made from treadmills" to a "treadmill made from treadmills on another treadmill" of sorts.

TLDR: Place the infinadeck on another x-y axis rig to manipulate the person's position in 3D space while the infinadeck deals with keeping the person in the same place relative to the ring.

I have been thinking of this idea since the DK2 but not sure if it is feasible.

As we can track feet, why not have a robotic mirror version of your feet flipped upside down under your feet, like a landing plate for you to walk on. It would look like you were walking on a mirror of yourself. So you take a step and one of the hydraulic foot plates matches your foot position in X,Y then stops as your actual foot comes down to land on it at the Z (height) plane. Then as you take a step it moves towards your center of mass but in VR it looks like you have stepped forwards. These plates under your feet can track any position so you could run, spin, jump, climb stairs, walk up or down hills and in the real world the plates are moving around to act as a dynamic floor, in VR it is near-like the real thing. The only element missing would be inertia so there would be a brain-body disconnect, a harness would be required.
Obviously this is more robotics and tracking than treadmill but it would allow for more motion. More costly and more dangerous too I imagine.

A spin off this idea is to have an Exoskeleton around your legs and hips while you are harnessed. The foot plate is inside the exoskeleton so it only slides up to meet your foot when you touch ground level and then it goes rigid as you take a step then as your leg raises the foot plate moves down and away from your actual foot. This removes any dangerous hydraulic arms from the concept although it has less resistance for that real life feeling.

Another idea is walking inside a cube which is like an inverted and fluid pin cushion, combine this with the Infinideck. The pins act like the CG geometry but always recenter you as you move about. You could even represent objects or other people with the pin rods. I think something like this was mentioned in a book I read years ago about an A.I. computer on an island.

comment_text: I don't understand why people are trying to make these large and expensive pieces of equipment. It's not marketable and definitely not sensible. I've realized the only obvious approach to this is so simple. When XBOX users use a game with Kinect, the little cameras in the machine are programmed to watch for certain body movements. If you wanted to walk, run, or turn you could just simply do it in place without actually going anywhere. The cameras could be programmed to respond to this type of movement and make the scenery in your game move accordingly. So while you would be going nowhere in reality, your virtual self would be propelled forward by the graphics. The only problem I can see with this scenario is that if the player for some reason were to get too immersed in the game and start actually walking they might hit a wall or something else in the room. So what I'm thinking is that those cameras need to also be programmed to watch for actual walking and warn the user immediately on screen that he or she is in probable danger. Sounds pretty feasible to me.

Hey Destin, first of all, nice video. Second, i believe that the biggest problem that virtual reality faces today, is the immersion issue. Now i have an idea for a virtual reality immersion device which is very cheap and easy to build, and with current technology very profitable to mass produce. For obvious reasons i will not go into further detail, but i can safely say that the road this company travels is not the right road. My idea will use direct input from the user itself, which can even be analog or digital, in stead of continuous scanning and reacting to the position of the user. Which in my opinion is never going to work perfectly, simply because there are a lot of calculations needed for getting the position and moving the device accordingly. Let alone the distance the signals have to travel. My idea eliminates every millisecond of lag, and can theoretically use the common joystick interface of any computer or console. Which is definitely a must for backwards compatability. Now, i haven't got a prototype yet, simply because i don't have the knowledge or money needed to build one. If you are interested, maybe you can contact me for building a prototype, and i will provide you with detailed information on how to build it. And who knows, maybe we will get very rich very fast, by solving the greatest problem VR has faced, ever. Last, keep up the good work, i enjoy all your videos! Greetings, Chris. Adding a solution (3d treadmill) while adding a fundamental problem (moving floor) isn't an elegant solution.

How about having your whole body in a fixed position, but slightly suspended while your foot is still in contact (ISS treadmill setup) & controlling the infinadeck (no motors), instead of using optical cam to tell the deck where to move, you use your legs to move the deck.

Could you use (additional) motion or gyro sensors on your hands, feet, and head (or better; knees, elbows, and hips) to attempt to predict the user's intent? As in, if those sensors are in a more expected motion, such as the motion involved in taking a step the computer will assume the proper velocity, but if a motion tracker stops or slows relative to the expected motion or in counter to the acceleration provided by the treadmill... Then the computer calculates a "stopping" motion and slows down or eliminates the expected velocity of the user when determining the output to the treadmill.

The issue with the Infinadeck is exactly what made me think of a "better" alternative to the multi-treadmill with virtual adaptation of the footing.

The issue with this method is the complexity of weight balance in the motion where the threadmill has to simulate the complex directional movement almost in advance so that it doesn't feel like you're pull in the wrong direction. To fix this issue, you got to add lot of calculation to balance things out and, as state in the video, it's not really possible to have it perfect due to the fact that it can't read your brain.

The solution I though about (which is one of those "up-to-come" idea I'm keeping for the future) is that instead using the treadmill as just an adaptator which requires motors and quite a bit of calculation to balance the footing range and zeroing the user in the center, why not just using it as an input device in a similar way to the old computer's mouse ball.

This solution would allow the whole device to be actually compatible even with VR situation which involves positions that aren't possible using the zeroing balancing feature of the Infinadeck. For example, the Infinadeck doesn't allow you to be in something like a racing car as you can't really be in a sitting position. The same applies if you're trying to be in a couch or prone position as the device has quite some limitation there.

In the case of the Ready Player One movie, what I'm writing about can even be seen in a way where the player are attached by strings from the roof (while in the truck) or with the player being attached with a kind of jacket to a spine structure.

Having the strings to be adjusted to the right height so that the player can touch the ground just enough to "push" the treadmills and using that movement of the treadmills as direct input would be so easy to implement with so little computation that it could also be compatible with existing titles in a matter of days (for movements in the world). The elevation would be what would requires the most work in this solution as the elevation would have to be calculated based on the position of the body parts in the virtual world. Again, this is still relatively simple, in terms of information and data, to get from a digital world. Body parts based physics isn't anything new after all as it's already quite used with the Ragdolls of any modern games.

The VR set of 6 points to recognize the avatar's position is quite in the right direction with the Infinadeck.

Is it strange that I somehow know how they made that treadmill?
PS: Augmented reality is actually the future.

Adding a "z" axis of movement will enable the treadmill to accurately simulate movement with minimal impact to the user. For instance, if the user moves forward, the treadmill slants forward. The forward tilt of the plane would trigger the treadmill to move "uphill", which would counter the feeling of the downhill slant. The forward slant can then be gradually reduced based upon the weight placement of the user. When the user stops, the opposite happens, meaning a backward slant to counter the stopping of the treadmill. The slanting mechanism should be entirely weight based, and the movement of the treadmill should be calculated on the transfer of weight distribution from one side of the foot to the other. This would be possible for any movement, as weight distribution is guaranteed no matter if side stepping, walking backwards, or even jumping. It could predict forward momentum of a stationary jump and move the treadmill backward and slant forward at the same time to prevent the user from actually moving, and return to level position once the user leaves the treadmill plane.

People normally walk on the ground, which makes them push forward against the forces of gravity. You won't feel that push on a treadmill, in fact, when you stop using the treadmill for long enough, you'll have a weird sense of motion as you move or stand still.

Wouldn't it make more sense to center the treadmill based on your foot positions? You'd have faster feedback for the player getting ready to move and you wouldn't get the sway "overcorrection" because your feet wouldn't move as much.

Additionally, if they made a sort of dead zone in the center, then it would not constantly be trying to micro-adjust when the person has come to a standstill, and is, for example, leaning back and forth.

They are suspended the up in the air which allows for 3 dimensions of movement not just 2 like this treadmill. If the user was suspended up a few feet in the air with some kind of boots and a harness, then, they’ll be able to simulate things like climbing, falling and even going upside down. There’s no reason for your feet to have contact with the ground in order to simulate a flat surface. A special pair of boots suspended in the air could simulate everything from stairs, sand, or even a rocky surface by changing the pressure applied to the boots much like an exercise bike that can simulate a hill by increasing the amount of force needed to move forward.

I wonder how much of their jerking problem could be solved through the use if a PID system. For those who don't know what that is, PID stands for Proportional, Integrational, and Derivative (Terms anyone who has taken calculus will instantly recognize). The PID part of a program attempts to correct movement by increasing the amount of counteraction the longer that there is a variation from normal, but it also tries to smooth the correction as it approaches normal.  In my case when I was younger we used PID for a line follower, and I'm curious whether people think this might help.

I feel like I've seen better designs for omnidirectional treadmills. Beyond the lag and over-compensation problems of this design, I think the ring around you would be a major hand/controller-breaking hazard for any game where you're swinging your arms around. This design would work, but they'd need to pretty much eliminate the lag time between you moving, the sensor noticing you moving, the sensor relaying the exact information of how you're moving to whatever computer is controlling the treadmill, and the computer getting the treadmill to move. I think that's just too long of a loop to get instantaneous enough, and seeing you stumble around as it lurched you forward and backward shows that this could never be used for anything more intense than just a sight-seeing game.

It's impossible to mimic the feeling of normal acceleration in a confined area. Think about Newton's Second Law: if you were to be able to feel the acceleration just as you normally start to walk, you would be moving with respect your original coordinates by the time you are walking, namely, you would be walking away from the treadmill.
It's the same with normal treadmill; the acceleration and deceleration process is not like actual walking at all. The feeling would only be normal when you are walking at a constant speed.
I guess unless you can find a way to cheat body of the feeling of acceleration, theoretically there isn't a solution to such weirdness.

I'm interested in seeing how the issue of the deck discerning intent changes if the intent is conveyed from the user via directioal controls in-game. For users who have relatie ease in immersion while playing, I've found (from personal experience and asking my peers) that walking on a traditional treadmill while imputing directional intent in a handheld game resulted in body drift. (It's the same effect as when you veer in the direction you're looking towards when walking, driving, biking, etc.) I suspect that if you input directional movement on the controller as you normally do with analog sticks/d-pads, and that the deck and VR landscape begins to both simultaneously moving accordingly, the player will be able to anticipate and inherently follow along. Basically, flip the issue on its head.

just being curious, i'm thinking, how about instead of trackers on each feet, they detect where the pressure points are on the treadmill, and center the mid point of them, to keep your body centered. so ultimately, this is just a simple movement controller. (i've just came up with a weird thought right now, imagine they made a mini version for your fingers to do the walking xD) so anyway, you're standing in the center, you move a foot forward, it centers you by shifting your back a tiny bit. if it slightly over shoots, i'd say, don't let it ever confuse the player by shifting back again, just wait for the player to take his next step, and center him like always. it's the ultimate sync. a.k.a the treadmill will know at the current moment, the player isn't centered, so when the player moves, one foot forward, it understands the difference like always, but also overshoots him back to the center in the moving direction. it's unnoticeable. and as the technology continues to get improved, the accuracy of the shifting will continue to improve, and will only be a just in case sync aspect. it's still going to understand exactly the motion the player moved, but still re-center.

and what if the person is on one foot, then hops to the other foot? you wouldn't want somebody's foot being dragged to the center and probably tripping. so this sync up fixes that completely, it just waits for the user to put down his other foot down. it's just for the safety of the player in the real world. if he wants to be weird and hop for some reason, he can, but the technology won't move him. he can hop into the barrier, and realize when you're running after enemies with a gun, hopping isn't really effective. if in the game, the player needs to jump, they could detect the player crouching, then the pressure vanishing. wherever the players feet land is the direction jumped.

actually, i used pressure to explain the syncing easier. the syncing can still be implemented with trackers. it can still be simulated the exact same way. you know where the treadmill is, where the feet are in relation to it. if they're on the ground or in the air, which foot the player is balancing on, etc... so trackers are more accurate, and specifically for the jumping. so when both your feet leave the base level (or ground zone), it's then using the direction they headed in to jump, at the exact same time as the player, instead of after he lands back on the treadmill.

and also, perhaps for jumping/hopping, the user has to hold onto the barrier, for the users safety in the real life. and you can still jump forwards/backwards/left/right with your feet. (quick reminder, when jumping, the treadmill doesn't need to shift anywhere. it only does that to center the player, when he walks) what would really be interesting is wall running like in black ops 3. they'd really need to up their game, and add some harness for you to sit in, which can raise you off the ground when you jump your feet onto the spiral wall treadmill underneath the railing. which would mean to get in this thing, you'd have to climb in/out, like it's a hot tub. lol

also, the wall running wouldn't be a necessary, it wouldn't actually be tracking movement, it'd just be an experience for the player to feel, and the treadmill part of it, just to keep the players feet in the same place, almost like a hamster. xD

anyway. those are just my random thoughts.

I think one way to solve the drift issue would be with a larger deck, with a physical ring still to aid in not falling off, but then also with a smaller ring acting as a deadzone. The system would try to keep you inside the deadzone, and movements within the deadzone would be effectively ignored. So your simple shifting of your weight won't result in the system trying to recenter you.
Downside, this thing is already pretty dang big, and the ideal situation, I think, would effectively be a whole room system.

...want to jump that PID loop feedback issue? Add 4 spools of spring-loaded "auto recovery winches" [+x,-x,+y,-y] and feed that into your PID loop (cascade that value to the motor's PID). This will measure your physical distance to the center...and get rid of that over/under shoot in your PID...Basically it'll tell the PID loop you're moving forward (and their current PID will control motors) and you're 0.1 meters +x from TDC(start position) so when you stop it already has an array value storing your +x,-x,+y,-y values from TDC and instantaneously act to put the spools back in their TDC position.

Where's the pressure growing, where's the pressure shrinking, and with instant feedback on physical location it should be able to calculate the force it needs to keep you relatively centered.
I say relatively centered because if it's constantly making micro adjustments to move you an inch or so it's going to throw you off-balance. It'd be better to give it a smaller circle within the bigger circle to nudge you into rather than a dot.
Last and probably most difficult to overcome would be to make the treadmill way, way lighter. It requires too much power to move that much mass around and it makes everything jerk around. My mind immediately jumps to something more like a large group of ball-bearings and a similar design to an old computer mouse ball. You may be able to stand on these balls directly, or if they want to create a plane to walk on perhaps a sheet of carbon fiber with tiny gaps in it and the balls have omni-directional gears to grip it with.

I'm just spitting out ideas though. I'm not actually an engineer or anything.

+SmarterEveryDay, How about adding 4-6 pressure sensor based elastic straps from the waist belt to the ring, where we can capture the variable of partial posture incline as a feedback of intent of direction we want to walk in?!
This feedback could help the program to make the treadmill intuitively start a bit earlier or stop in time.
And also probably the increasing pressure due to stretching of elastic in one particular direction can help our brain to intuitively slow down the body (just like our brain self-adjusts to the traditional treadmill inertia). So this brain's intuitive slow down + the 360° treadmill's quicker & more proportional response to the elastic stretch feedback, can make the whole walking response more accurate compared to the contact struggle of positioning the gamer in the center with the treadmill's later lag.

Apart from this, due to the pressure feedback & straps, we may not need the ring to be visible within the game because by sensing the minor pressure on the waist belt due to the straps, you'll know exactly how far from center you're and won't accidentally trip over

hi, I'm Alberto, I'm from Italy and I'm a mechanical engineering student
to solve this problem (or at least try to improve the machine) you should wear an other sensor on your body, in particolar on your chest. if you want to walk you have to lean forward before your first step. with just one sensor you will always have a delay on the response of the sistem because the person has already leant but the sensor doesen't know that. by using two sensors and computing the different position between the two, you can predict the direction of the movement as well as how fast the person is going to move. using this sistem the algorithm can also be activated before the fist step and the delay in the response will be shorter.

Though this does highlight the two big issues of VR that might not be solved any time soon... gauging intent, and providing some realistic sensation of acceleration (including that due to gravity when in an orientation other than standing straight up). The former probably needs some kind of EEG that can read your brainwaves and learn what pattern corresponds to "about to walk forwards" (etc), the latter will demand some way of overriding the signals coming from the inner ear and will probably be a much knottier problem.
