I know how to fix the positive and negative acceleration problem they are experiencing:

By tagging sensors up and down the body, specifically important would be those on the feet, the sensors can detect whether the feet are separated from the treadmill, the angle at which the legs are separated, and the motion of the feet. Estimating the path of the user allows for a more gradual change in directional acceleration. Estimating the speed at with the user is moving based on the angle of separation of the legs, and tilt of the body, allows for an accurate gauge of deceleration.

Inputting these estimated variable changes will greatly decrease the overshot of the system in repositioning the user.

I would also make the central point the user’s center of mass should be located much larger to compensate for lag time and excess calculations associated with estimated variables.

If they use my ideas, I would love to meet the crew and potentially get comped the first production model, haha.

I think putting the center of mass as 6 inches in front of the back is flawed. You can see at the around 8:05 Destin gets into a feedback loop where the deceleration of the treadmill causes his hips to move to the side further than it should, and then repeats that on the other side.

I think it might work better if the center of mass was calculated to be the midpoint between the feet, if they're tracking them already. That way it could start much earlier (and thus have a more accurate acceleration), and there's not a possibility for the feedback loop / tracker sway, because the trackers are so close to the ground, and fixed on your feet.

This will probably never be seen by Infinadeck, but even so, may I suggest a change to the tracking control? You're right, the biggest hurdle with the machine is decreasing the response time. Currently you're trying to do so based on cg position, which is non-predictive. However, if you change the tracking control to feet position, you could write an adjusted algorithm that is “predictive,” and therefore could essentially be instantaneous, no major dampening necessary. It might require a bit more math and programming skills, but I think it is the only way to get the response time and disruption to the user near zero.
I would program the software to keep the user centered on the machine based on the center of mass of the user's two feet collectively. The machine could predict the direction the user will walk as soon as one foot starts to move, whether forward, backward, or sidestepping, and therefore start centering the user immediately, rather than waiting for the torso to catch up. Also, this means you could shift positions, sway on your feet, and bend over without triggering the machine. It would feel natural with minimal readjustment. Although placing the tracker for position control on the feet introduces additional z movement, the algorithm will continue to throw out z- axis information as I assume it does on the current iteration. Or...

A second (third?) generation design could eventually answer the problem of climbing in vr by using the z information from the feet position to map to vr and use some kind of hydraulic (for example) boot to provide z motion feedback, similar to a stepper exercise machine.
This is very hypothetical so I could be wrong about how this would work, but... Unlike a stepper, it will have to provide unequal resistance to the feet if necessary. Z-centering would have to depend on the vr map. If the “ground” is flat, the foot that's not stepping would stay at it's z-position. If climbing, the software would have to calculate the z-distance a foot would appear to travel for a given slope or item height and provide the appropriate resistance to the appropriate feet at the appropriate times: allowing non-resistive motion when the foot is in the “air” and providing resistance as soon as the foot teaches the level of the “slope,” meeting the foot at that point and then lowering down until the end of the stride. The goal of the algorithm for z-centering should be to keep the feet at a preset height above the deck, “above” so that stepping down can be possible. Not sure this is actually physically doable in combination with x and y as well, but I could see someone wearing boots and bring on the machine, or incorporating the x and y into the treads of a stepper/climber z-axis boot.

Invented an omni-directional treadmill over 10 years ago. Glad I never shared the design because it seems like nearly all of my intentions have finally surfaced, though most of them are lacking certain aspects and it's kind of funny to see them struggle with various obstacles, but failure is how people learn. Money has been the only obstacle in actually producing one. It was relatively easy to overcome the "delay" effect and remove any limits as to how fast you can run and have the treadmill remain responsive. The technology in this video at this time isn't very practical for a wide variety of games because the user would need some additional input if they were to want to come to a dead stop or jump after running fast. Not to mention power consumption, maintenance, cost to manufacture, and durability. Drop a few Doritos in this thing or get a shoelace caught and it's literally game over lmao. Still pretty cool though, can't wait to see how this technology develops.

@SmarterEveryDay I think I've got an interesting solution to their problem. If they haven't tried it already.

I think they could apply a recurrent neural network to learn the complex patterns of human intents from small changes in position of the sensors. I think there's a statistical correlation to be made there actually, which is essential to machine learning. They could later use this information of educated guesses to drive the treadmills better and prepare for the velocity changes almost instantly. Essentially minimizing the acceleration graph showed in the video.

The data they could use for training the neural network could be lots of motion capture of people running on solid ground. Centering them onto a fixed point in 3D space, and in that way simulating the ideal perfect treadmill. The network would then use the sensor positions as input and then have the inverse of acceleration as ground truth or goal. Given that it reaches a high enough accuracy, the network would in that way be able to propely map the position changes of the sensors to acceleration of the treadmill in real life, based on this history of data.

What if you combined an omnidirectional treadmill with a less ambiguous control system that defines avatar locomotion.

So let’s say your controller had an analog stick or a touch pad or whatever. Pressing forward on the controller moves the treadmill backwards relative to where your body is facing. The speed at which the treadmill moves during typical “walking” is customizable to the user. I imagine you would have the user take several steps forward backwards left and right to find these speeds.

Basically this means if I want to walk forward, I would slide my thumb forward on whatever controller as I start walking. At the same time, the treadmill accelerates relative to the acceleration of the controller input up to my set walking speed.

Potential challenges I see with this:

While I kinda got used to it I imagine people won’t be perfect at pressing forward exactly when they start walking forward. I think tracking systems like the infinadeck are necessary to make small corrections and keep the user in the center of the treadmill.

This only allows for one speed. If you want environments that allow users to walk at multiple speeds, you would need to record these as well. After that you could map a slow or fast option to buttons that are also pressed durning locomotion. (Plenty of games already have these in the form of sprint or stealth buttons).

The biggest problem I realized while writing this is turning. If I turn while walking, the infinadeck has to do the same guess work it does throughout the video. When will the user turn? At what rate will they turn? When will they stop turning?

If people could think up solutions to this, that would be good. The best thing I could think of is also mapping this turning to controls. If you want to keep this similar to common first person controls, one button controls what direction the body is in while the other controls which direction you walk relative to the avatar’s position.

And this seems like a lot more for the player to keep track of while walking.

So I am not sure what are their intention. The omnidirectional treadmills are not new. They are used, as big devices, especially in training and military. But they are rather big and expensive, it is also tricky to get motor power lines and control data into and out of the inner trademill.

These guys probably want to make it as small as possible, use tracking methods from VR (IR lasers, etc), and compensation. The problem with that is that they need very good positional and speed tracking accuracy, and have well optimized PID-like control of the trademill, because there is a lot of mass in the trademill + subject on it, speeds should be as big as possible on average, but the accelerations and jerks should be as small as possible, otherwise the noise will be high, and subject will get out of balance. The best way to achieve that is to have big trademill (with accurate and powerful motors), where you can afford smaller speeds and time to reposition subject back to the center, i.e. they can run and even jump around like crazy, and the trademill will still do its job fine, even if it is moving relatively slowly, because they also have time and space to accelerate and decelerate without subject noticing too much or getting out of balance.

It looks like they're using a "PID (Proportional, Integral, and Derivative)" algorithm to correct the difference in inertia, movement, or acceleration. Controllers in chemical plants and some other autonomous electronics use this technology, where the amount of "offset" from a desired value determines how much of a change the instrument, mechanism, or apparatus needs to make to cancel out the amount of error. It's a pretty simple formula, however, the challenge is actually implementing it and making it work in the real world.

I always wanted to ask, why don't they use the foot trackers instead of the hip to predict motion? A person would move their foot with the intent on changing or starting movement before their hip might lurch forward. If you throw away all the inertia and acceleration models they have now and instead use a slow and fast rebound system like car suspensions, it would even be possible for users to adjust this on their own and set it to their preferences.

Here's my idea for how they can do this:

FAST REBOUND: take the average of the players feet x,y coordinates and keep that at center at all times, with 100% speed and no added latency. If the player moves his foot forward 30cm, the treadmill moves back 15, setting both feet 15 cm apart from center. The player can change directions all the time without ever leaving the center of the treadmill. If the player begins to fall due to discomfort somehow, their feet would move away from center, and the machine would react to this in the same way, pushing the players feet right back under him/herself and preventing a fall. Because I have no way of testing this myself, I have to rely on imagination to think of what this might be like - when i take a step forward, the machine moves my foot backwards and keeps me standing, but I may feel a sense of tripping forward, or it may feel like my steps are longer than I intend. To counter this, the effect of fast rebound could be set at lower percentages, meaning it'll slow down movement instead of completely cancelling it: eg, at 50%, taking a 30cm step forward would only set the treadmill back 7.5 cm, I will now be 7.5 cm off center, but my movement is more natural. However the player will drift away from center, Hence, the second type of centering...

SLOW REBOUND: similar to the fast rebound, except it is capped at a certain acceleration rate to minimize the player feeling any unexpected inertia. If Fast rebound is set to 50% and the player is drifting away from center at half walking speed, the slow rebound will slowly accelerate to bring the player back to center, it is allowed to travel faster than the player to "catch up" and bring the player back to center, but velocity and direction are not allowed to change at a rate faster than a set amount, this is so that the unnatural recentering movement remains as subtle as possible, with the goal being that the player does not notice it at all.

From here the adjustments made will be a trade between comfort, playable space, and manoeuvrability. The higher the fast rebound, the faster the player can change directions, or run, but it may cause nausea/discomfort, or it may be difficult to get used to. The slower the fast rebound, the more natural the player movement will feel, but the player will drift from center. The lower the slow rebound, it becomes less noticeable for the player but the player can step out of bounds if changing direction or velocity too quickly - requires larger treadmill sizes, the faster the slow rebound, the more discomfort the player might feel when the machine centers, but the player drift will be more manageable with larger changes in velocity and direction, keeping high manoeuvrability with a smaller treadmill surface.

If the Fast Rebound works like I'd imagined, they only need to adjust the ratio of the two values to get it to feel comfortable, or they could start sales and leave those for users to adjust to their own preference, and they could sell different sizes of treadmill. Larger treadmills would allow more natural feeling movement without sacrificing the players reaction time and smaller treadmills have to sacrifice one of either.

Personally I'm far more interested in the body tracking going mainstream so we have proper tracked avatars instead of floating hands than the treadmill itself.

Playing VR in room scale (mine is 12' by 12' with Oculus) you get used very quickly to resetting your position and manage boundaries, plus in room scale you can do things like crouching (or even jumping) without having to worry about a treadmill. And once you get used to good teleporting (Robo Recall) or locomotion (SkyrimVR and Windlands are good examples) you suffer zero dizziness while playing for hours at a time.

So while treadmills are interesting in practical practice body tracking for presence and more tracked element integration in general is faaaaar more important in my opinion.

on the first look it seems something trivial to fix , but when you think about it is actually very complicated to get it working just right, the difficult part is that it needs to behave like a tread mill the moment you raise your foot and step and then switch and behave like a "ball Segway" the moment you want to stop.
i think a solution would involve keeping track of the distance between your feet and move the treadmill so the midpoint between them is always in the middle of the treadmill and leave the CG control to the user.
so in a situation where you have both your feet on the treadmill and you lean forward it would not move until you raise one foot and put it ahead to not fall on the ring.when you raise your foot to bring it forward you increase the distance between them and the midpoint moves forward so in that case the treadmill should move back but stop if you keep both feet in contact with the belt for longer than the average foot contact time for the walking speed you are currently at.
starting to walk and accelerating on it would not be a problem i think, the problem comes with the way ppl tend to run in which case they'r CG is always ahead of the midpoint between they'r feet and when they want to decelerate and come to a stop the CG moves back, so a trigger is needed when the user wants to stop from running where the treadmill will override the condition that puts the feet midpoint always in the center and start moving so that the CG is aligned with the midpoint .
it may also be the case that the CG check won't be needed at all if the user learns to run without any inertia reflex, AKA not moving the feet ahead of CG when wanting to stop.
it may feel just like running on ice, where you can't really run with your CG ahead of your feet nor come to a stop with it behind.
EDIT: just watched Tested's video about it and the CEO talks about how they are working on making it feel like natural walk instead of a frictionless surface so i guess they considered this but chose to go all the way and do it without compromising the natural feel.And that is impossible for short distance bursts, like where you accelerate to a certain speed then decelerate to a stop without any constant speed in between.
to have the acceleration feedback you need a bigger treadmill first and then you need a constant speed period in which the algorithm is moving you close to the center without you feeling it, and then when you want to stop it will actually move you towards the back of the treadmill so you feel like you will just fall if you don't put your feet's ahead of you.how fast it should move it depends on how fast you run and how far ahead you put your feet, so it's easy to see it requires a bigger treadmill the faster you want to run.

Acceleration problem arise partly because Infinideck has no Z axis.  People naturally brace themselves in the direction of a slight rise under their feet.  If your toes rise you lean forward, heels rise you lean backward.  Slight rises under toes or heel could encourage users to re-balance themselves more naturally instead of as a learned conditioning.  As an alternative to the difficulty of implementing a real addressable bumps on the Z axis, floating the corners on hydraulic struts and tilting the whole platform slightly could suffice.

Your feet are the intent, not your center of mass. They need to measure the pressure of an individual’s foot as well as use the direction of the foot that is not touching the tread. That gives you how hard you intend to move forward and in what direction. Trying to keep the belt center is just going to cause people to get thrown off balance. The first step you take was a good demonstration of that. If they were doing the calculations based on your feet, it wouldn’t have moved the ground left as you were taking a step with your left foot. I would also remove the handlebar ring and use a motorized suspended harness that would help offset any changes in inertia while centering you while your body is low to the tread. The treadmill also shouldn’t overshoot. If those are high action low response motors, they should be matching your stride and not moving you when you’re not moving. They should correct your location slightly with the next stride, just like we do when we run on a normal treadmill. Here’s a fun thought. Leaning forward and having the tread shoot your feet backwards while you eat the handrail. If your feet aren’t moving, you’re not intending to move. Even if one foot is moving, it’s not enough for intent, you need to measure force. We don’t walk like a pair of chop sticks falling from point to point.

So many comments, so maybe this has been said, but I think you missed a trick by not talking about jerk, the derivative of acceleration wrt time. Vihart and Tom Scott did good videos about this and it's especially relevant to your experience in that ring. Otherwise, great video, as always.

So they are trying to solve a PID loop problem, where the load and it's center of gravity vary from person to person, an the load moves around on it's own (pesky human!) That is formidable. As you said, when you get on a treadmill, the brain solves all these problems effortlessly, so why not let the brain do the work on the VR version? You would use a controller to move forwards, backwards, and side to side just like you would without a treadmill, but the treadmill would then move in that direction, at a fixed speed, forcing the person to walk in lock step with it to stay on. The illusion, once moving, would work. In other words, think of a person controlling a treadmill in real life, changing the speed, incline, etc, but also being able to change the direction of the treadmill, and then simply walking at the right speed/direction to stay on it.
These guys are on thr right track. No pun intended.

This is a great example of over engineering . You don't need any of this. I'm going to outline a much better and simpler system:

The user is held stationary by a belt around the waist, or a harness around the torso. The harness is held stationary via a bar attached to the floor. Imagine a 5 foot street lamp, only with a harness instead of a lamp at the end. The users feet have sensors. His feet are free to move. User is wearing roller skates or slippery shoes on a friction less surface. Displacement of feet is used to calculate VR velocity and displacement. You no longer need the mechanical treadmill and all the hassle that entails. You only need to compute VR displacement. There is no longer a negative bio-feedback loop from the threadmill momentum.

Destin, wonderful video!  I have an idea that maybe you could pass to the guys down at Infinadeck.  They have likely thought of this already, but I wanted to share my idea just in case.  What if, instead of an exact point in space, they used a bubble for maintaining the user's CG in the center of the treadmill.  It may allow for damping of the accelerations/decelerations by not forcing the user onto a specific spot.  This may fix the back and forth that you experienced when you stopped abruptly.  It is similar to the sensitivity of joysticks on drones and other RC devices and video games.  The more precise sensitivity leads to jumpy controls versus the smoother movement that comes with lower sensitivity.  However, they would need to find a balance between increased and decreased sensitivity by modifying the size of the bubble to avoid excessive lag.  Perhaps a logarithmic or exponential algorithm would suffice in finding the balance.  Anyway, that's my idea!  Thanks for the videos!!!

Hey Destin, have them incorporate pneumatics.  In animatronics, they use pneumatics to replicate lifelike movements alongside electronic actuators and electronic servos.  The pneumatics act as a cushion layer that perfectly duplicate the movements of people, where as electronic servos by themselves are so "perfect" and un-lifelike that they cause jerkyness and either overshoot or cause abrupt halts.  I think in this case, the correct use of pneumatics would be the perfect implementation to overcome the limitations they are encountering.

Even if the treadmills timing was perfect, it still couldn't perfectly simulate real gait since the acceleration/velocity is externally driven rather then internally driven, so your body is responding a bit differently. For example in a classic treadmill the back leg is advanced partially by the velocity of the machine, while in regular gait a person must actively extend at the hip and contract the hamstrings without the aid of the momentum from the treadmill.

I would think a large ball-ish device not much taller than that treadmill would work. The top of the ball would be flat (I suppose the bottom could be as well, so it'd be like a toroid but no hole) . The underlayment of the ball would covered in ball bearings of some sort to allow the skin to move freely in any direction. Then there would be several motors-rollers that hold onto the skin and move it in any direction. This would help with inertia of the motors/belts that is evident in this device shown, and it would allow for true 360Deg movement without effecting the feet of the player. Even tho the tracks will move, they are still locked in 90Deg rotation of the main drive. I'm sure this rotation can be felt. This also makes it harder for your brain to adapt to the new motion as it's quite unnatural in motion.
Perhaps if the computer was faster in the processing, or the programming was put in, it could sense your feet slowing down, there by slowing down the motor drives as well. It seemed like the guy explaining what was going on was basically saying it only monitors the back piece and tries to keep it centered. It would make more sense (albeit more computations need to be done) to use all 3 points (back and feet) to know where the person is on the treadmill. Your feet start to move in a particular direction before you back even begins to move. And same with slowing down. The distance between the feet narrows between steps as the person slows down before the back can slow down.
A treadmill is NOT a simple device! It has to observe when you step and put in more energy to keep the band going at that pace given change in momentum... More than simple.

Things topple over when center of gravity is past the base of support.  It seems like they need to determine where the center of gravity is located on a person.  Then attach a device around that area of the body.  Then use sensors to read exactly where the feet are located on the treadmill (or above the treadmill).  Then the machine can tell if a person is getting ready to move, stop, etc, by reading where the center of gravity is located relative to it's base of support.  Basically, if a person is getting ready to run, their center of gravity is shifted forward relative to the base of support.  When they suddenly stop from a sprint, their center of gravity falls way behind the base of support.

The control systems problem with this is that when I start walking forwards, I'll lean forwards at first to overcome intertia and keep my CoG between my feet. A treadmill that tries to centre my body immediately would pull my feet out from under me just as I'm off-balance. It needs to allow the user's balance to adjust to a walking gait before even starting to accelerate to keep the CoG in the middle of the ring. Likewise, if you suddenly stop walking you'll plant your front foot down with all your weight on that foot, which means your CoG is behind it; if the treadmill decelerates at all at that point you'll fall over backwards. It'll be some pretty impressive algorithms that manage to make a convincing experience in that small a bounding area.

Maybe the solution is to add 2-axis tilt to the platform, to compensate for the missing inertial effect? Then as you lean into a gait, it tilts back to meet you, keeping you upright and centred over your feet.

My question is this: Why are they bothering with optical motion tracking? Granted it's certainly the easiest method, but it also seems to be the source of a lot of extra variables and lag.

Now, I realize how hard something like this would be but... what if the treadmill worked similarly to a multi-touch touch screen? Or, specifically, a two-touch touch screen. If it could read the application of weight at all points and redirect the movement of the floor based on that? Or, to put it another way, the treadmill could simulate friction.

For example, when you step forward, you press backward against the floor with force opposite the direction you want to move in. Then, the distance your next foot strides away could be used to calculate velocity. The force you exert with your landing foot could be used to calculate acceleration. And the pressure applied all around the treadmill could directly be converted into positional data of your location on the treadmill itself without it having to be translated from optical sensors and then calculated.
What's the learning curve on this? Is there a certain amount of time that it takes, on average, for a person to master it?

Super cool, with some great possibilities for scientific research!  I've been thinking about a similar thing, but in a much simpler way, for a while.  I'm doing a PhD in hearing research, and am looking at how our vestibular system affects where we think sounds are coming from.  I'd though a really cool thing to do would be to have someone wear a motion tracking headset and turn from side to side, but have a robotic chair turn their body so their head stays still. I think they may want to try centering at a lower point on the body.

By centering the waist they have to tackle the issue of a person leaning and then the treadmill correcting.
If they centered the point between the two feet then the person could lean slightly without causing the treadmill to activate and throw them off balance.
Also the feet are the only objects that need to interact with the treadmill and so keeping them near the center and therefore on the treadmill surface is more important than keeping the waist in the center.
When walking you also lean before moving your feet and so having the ground move and being forced to move your feet early might be the cause of the unnatural feeling describe in the video.

I imagine they have tried this, but it would be interesting to know if they have and if there is a reason they are focusing on the center of gravity.

I wonder how long it'll be until it's feasible for them to set up a deep learning optimization loop. Set up pre-recorded simulations of people moving, simulate the Infinadeck's responses to them, put virtual sensors on the people to record what the accelerations on them are like (though the simulated people themselves wouldn't react, because if we had a simulation that could do that we'd already have an algorithm that could solve this without iteration). Set up an AI to play with the control variables, iterate until the simulations are within a predetermined margin of user comfort, then repeat with new simulations.

It'd require a lot of processor time and probably a PhD or two of expertise to set up, but that's time and expertise they should hopefully be able to afford once v1 hits the market and they're working on v2.

It seems like some of these problems could be easier if the deck were larger. It could give the computer more time to determine intent in a more accurate way. I think it would also allow the treadmills to accelerate more gradually, making the whole experience more natural feeling.

My ideas for solutions (and why some wouldn't work) (although they've probably already thought of these):
--Track the feet in relation to the "back" node. That way the system can "expect" movement, because unless you're reaching your foot out to touch something, you're probably about to move.
--Track the head in relation to the "back" node. We move primarily by putting our head in front of our center of mass, the walk to "catch" it. We use our head for lots of simple movement. So if you're leaning your head forward, you're about to move, so the system can be prepared to move.
The problem with tracking the head is that if our feet don't "catch" our head, we fall forward, and the infinadeck is basically pulling our feet out from under us. So our head needs to be above our center of mass for the infinadeck to work.

While not integral to the system, it's worth mentioning that it's not really a treadmill made of treadmills. The Y direction isn't a dozen little treadmills, it's one band that is wrapped around the larger X-treadmill like a string or helix. Then they only have to drive the direction in one way rather than calibrating 30 smaller treadmills.

This can't ever be improved to feel right. I started thinking about if you matched the inertia to the user and had 0 friction in the mechanism you could have the treadmill move from your own motor force, but then I realized this would just cut your walking speed in half (equal and opposite reactions). To stay perfectly centered you would need 0 friction and 0 inertia, but that would just feel slippery like ice.

Only way is probably if you fixed the center of mass to the center of the treadmill in X and Y (allowing sliding along Y). This combined with inertia matching and low friction would probably feel real good, because then all the reaction forces our legs are used to would be there, it's just the treadmill that's moving rather than the body.

The deck needs to be much larger and the ring needs to be mobile. Instead of recentering you inside of the ring, the system needs to reposition the ring to be center around you. This would be limited by the amount of space available, but I imagine the g-forces from trying to nudge your body towards the center of the room would be MUCH lower then trying to reposition you completely INSIDE of a ring, especially one so small.

The G-forces on the ring wouldn't matter, the ring isn't a part of your body and wouldn't break immersion like this does.

This makes me think of the gravity on space stations problem. With a small station the forward and backward momentum is great enough from a spin that you can feel it and it is disorienting. Make the station large enough, and this effect shrinks to the point where you can no longer consciously feel it. I imagine the same could be said for the g forces in the moving floor; larger movements like running could be used to correct the position in the room while smaller movements like a step or two across the room wouldn't make the floor move if at all, to prevent feeling the g-forces.

I saw this rig on the Tested channel, too. Been thinking about it. I think there is another problem that you missed. When we walk in the real world, we're constantly adjusting our center of gravity. Once they can rotate the treadmill surface, introducing pitch in real time, then I suspect they could solve for this balance problem better.

The funny part is how all these VR are machines are one day gonna be completely redundant.
We are in the process of building all these super complicated machines that emulate a reality by pretending to be a something that our senses will then communicate to the brain which in turn will hopefully interpret it as close to the real deal as possible.

In other words, we are "inventing" *electrical signals* that try to simulate a *physical environment* for our physical senses to translate back to an *electrical signal* that will be interpreted by our brain and then hopefully be as close as possible to the original signal.
The funny part is that one day we're probably just gonna get rid of that entire process and "feed" the signals directly to the brain, Matrix-style.

I spent years doing light fighting in the SCA (the short version of that explanation is historical recreation fencing). As a "fencer" I found there were 3 levels of learning.
first you're learning how to put your feet where you need to put them, then move them in the way and direction you want to move them, while moving your arms and body to avoid taking a hit while trying to land one on your opponent. There's a lot of moving parts you need to get your brain to do at the same time to not look clumsy.

second level is when you have done it enough so you've trained your body what to do in what circumstances and your muscle memory is such that you're no longer thinking "ok, move the left foot forward no more than shoulder width forward to stay in balance, now pull the back foot up, staying in stance and shift your weight." Now you're thinking "move forward". You effectively are driving from 3rd person. Now it's "slide forward, parry high, disengage, move laterally to the right and fire at his leg". you have a running conversation with your body to tell it where to go and what to do.

third level i consider mastery. you're not longer consciously thinking of what you need to do, you just do it. at this point you've trained enough so what you're doing is looking for patterns and openings while doing all the things from before almost before you realize you need to do them.

the muscle on his front leg bunches, signaling to you he's about to throw a shot, so you're already moving out of the path and throwing your own.

my point to all this is. This technology is at level one.

body mechanics, the way you shift your weight, when you tense specific muscles indicate well before you do something that you're about to do it. Senors on those places would let you adjust almost in real time. The treadmill would know you're shifting to a different direction or speed before you even consciously knew it yourself.

I figured it out. We just need a way for the system to read the processes that should be happening in the brain as if a person were actually walking on a treadmill, so that the brain does the bulk of the processing. You can see the conflict between what Destin's brain thinks should be happening if he was walking on a regular treadmill, and what the computer is saying should be happening.

I did one project where i studied VR, back when 1st Oculus was on developer phase. The conclusion i came up with: VR will work if you commandeer a vehicle of some sorts. We move inside the vehicle freely in the VR and in the real life. Matching geometry is needed to position the two in VR and real life. We can accept delays and lags what we get from the paradox: "it can't know what you are going to do" which it always needs. Giving the user matching geometry between real life and VR and fully embracing the "vehicle" concept: it works. There isn't even motion sickness as such. For ex, in an FPS game, we are inside a mech, piloting it. The character model can be a human scale and so can we, we just have to somehow make us believe that we are inside a thing and that the "thing" moves in the VR.

The vehicle acts as a translator between the two worlds and our minds can accept that.

I like the ring idea here, i'm quite sure this is first part of the solution, it acts as our "anchor" and translator, plus it gives HUGE feeling of safety to have physical object around and that you can grab it at any time. The inertia.. Oh boy, unsolvable, me think in this configuration. Too much mass. I always dreamed that 360 treadmill uses tiny spheres to simulate rolling ground, using the vehicle idea; you don't move: you move the ground... I'm sure we can understand even rolling the entire earth with our feet, which also explains the lack of acceleration and the eventual problem of "how do we get back to the center of our area..".. that jerk must feel like the earth moves so.. why not embrace the fault and make the earth move in the VR..
